div.head: THE TRANSLATOR TO THE LOYALL Hearted Subiects of ENGLAND.
div.p:
AS the Author of this ≈ømall Treati≈øe te≈øtifieth him≈øelfe to be a true hearted ≈øubiect to the Crowne of France, by compo≈øing it; J will likewi≈øe (in emulation and imitation of his fidelity) approue my ≈øelfe to be no le≈ø≈øe to the Crowne of England, by tran≈ølating it. For ≈øith this bloudy booke of Cardinal Bellarmine (ambitiou≈øly arrogating to him≈øelfe the Title of the
Popes Temporall power) though particularly ≈øent to France, is neuerthele≈ø≈øe meant, and doth concerne all other Kingdomes, Soueraignties and free States what≈øoeuer; I thought in honour to God, in alleageance to my Prince, in loue to my Countrie, and in duetie to all, J was bound to di≈øpoile out of his French habilements, and to ≈øute in our Engli≈øh attire this iudicious and compendious Treati≈øe, which ≈øo worthily oppo≈øeth and impugneth it. Come, nay then run, if not flie hither, you loyall hearted Engli≈øh men, and as the choi≈øe of the wi≈øest, chiefe≈øt and loyalle≈øt hearted French haue already, ≈øo in religion, in zeale, in di≈øcretion and iu≈øtice doe you now commit and ≈øacrifice to the fire both Bellarmines booke, and the thought, much more the practi≈øe of tho≈øe irreligious, v≈øurping and ≈øanguynat ≈øpeeches and po≈øitions therein contained, tending
to the di≈øgrace, preiudice, and de≈øtruction both of our Kings & Countries; yea for euer (in your hearts and ≈øoules) not onely ≈øpit at, but defie the wrongfull, tyrannicall, Je≈øuiticall and Diabolicall pretence of this (Sophi≈øticall traytor, and treacherous Sophi≈øter) Bellarmine, who (as ≈øubtlely as inueterately) aimeth, not to reach at, but to take off the Crownes of Kings, and (iniu≈øtlie) to place them vpon the heads of Popes; yea to trample their Scepters and Regall Ornaments vnder their feet, and to bring their Dominions and ≈øubiects, both into a wofull de≈øolation and a mi≈øerable ≈øubiection and ≈ølauerie.

For alas, ≈øhall we permit to ≈øee, or liue to permit that our Roiall Kings of England (not inferior to anie, but equall with the greate≈øt Kings of the world) ≈øhould now (through our negligence) be made homagers, ≈øubiects, nay ≈ølaues vnto Popes
(Gods mortall enemies, and our deadly profe≈ø≈øed foes) as was our King Iohn, the Emperour Fredericke Barbaro≈ø≈øa, the King of Nauarre, and Earle of Tholou≈øe, &c.)

No, no, illustrious and generous Nobilitie, iudicious and faithfull priuie Coun≈øellors, learned and vpright Judges, reuerend and religious Prelates, valorous and warlike Gentry, incorruptible and watchfull Magi≈øtrates, faithful and vigilant Officers, obedient and loyall Commons; ioine all in one, yea, let euery mothers ≈øonne (if occa≈øion require) with an vnanime con≈øent, Viua Voce, cheerfully and couragiou≈øly, with Drummes beating, Trumpets ≈øounding, and Canons roaring, denounce Warre to that Cardinall, nay to that Pope, nay to that diuell, which pre≈øumeth or dur≈øt pre≈øume to depriue either our King of his ≈øoueraigntie,
or our Countrey of her independencie: yea next and immediatly to the zeale of the glory of God, let vs be zealous & watchfull, watchful and couragious, couragious and re≈øolute, for the ≈øecuritie and pre≈øeruation of King IAMES our dread Soueraigne, and his heires for euer; and for the con≈øeruation and maintaining of the Soueraigntie, both of his Crowne and Kingdome of England, the Paradice of the world, and our ≈øweet natiue Countrie.

And the more to incite, and powerfully incourage you in the performance of this your religious and ≈øworne duety; I haue tran≈ølated, publi≈øhed, and here pre≈øent you this Toc≈øin, (or Watch-bell) that when you chaunce to ≈øleepe in your beddes of ≈øecuritie, it may arou≈øe and awake you to ≈øtand vpon your guard, with Swordes drawne, Muskets charged, Match lighted, and hearts eagerlie ≈øharpened and animated to de≈øtroy and
confound the Pope and his adhaerents, and to ≈øubuert and ouerthrow all other ho≈øtile enemies what≈øoeuer, which ≈øhal either incroach vpon our Temporalitie, or attempt to depriue vs of our Soueraignty; to the end that neither the fame and renowne of our decea≈øed triumphant and victorious warriours (which hath heretofore ≈øpread it ≈øelfe to the farthe≈øt and remote≈øt parts of the world, and is for euer characteris'd vpon the neuer-dying Records of immortality) may not de≈øeruedly taunt & taxe vs with the ≈øcandalous imputation of cowardi≈øe, nor our po≈øteritie hereafter, reuile and cur≈øe vs for leauing them inheritors and heires, onely to Tyrannicall ≈ølauery, and Presbyteriall ≈øeruitude: from the which God of his mercy pre≈øerue & defend both our ≈øelues and them. And hereunto let all the loyall hearted ≈øubiects of King Iames clappe hands, and ≈øay Amen, Amen.

div.head: THE TOCSIN OR, WATCH-BELL.
div.p: FRance, it is high time (without delay) that this Toc≈øin (or Watch-bell) ≈øound ≈øhrilly in the hearts of all thy people, to awake and giue the Alarum to all tho≈øe which ought to defend thee; ≈øith Cardinall Bellarmine the Ie≈øuite (as impudently as vniu≈øtly) hath cho≈øen the right of thy Kings minority, to giue the a≈ø≈øault to thy Soueraignty, and to fixe the Petard to the gates of thy Maie≈øty, hitherto inuiolated.

He hath watched the time that thy Hercules Henry the great, was tran≈ølated to a better Kingdome then thine, to leaue the Supreintendency thereof ill a≈ø≈øured to the young King his heire, the Regency vncertaine to the Queene Regent, the ≈øucce≈øsion doubtfull to the Princes of blood, the authority decrepit
and feeble to the Parliaments, the care voy de of honour to the Magi≈øtrates, the loyalty without a≈ø≈øurance to the Officers, the obedience without fidelity to the Subiects, and the peace without continuance to our neighbours. For this booke publi≈øhed of late in Rome, vnder the title of The Popes Temporall power, hath performed all, yea farre wor≈øe then all this.

This proud Cardinall in his booke, depainteth vs Popes, as if each were a Cyrus, that is to ≈øay, inflamed with a de≈øire, both to haue and to commaund all: but our Queene Mary ≈øhall be to them a Tomiris, which authori≈øed and incouraged in the right of her ≈øonne, ≈øhall not onely cut off the complots of tho≈øe V≈øurpers, but al≈øo the intru≈øion of all others what≈øoeuer. An acte both iu≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øith it is not done in contempt of the Apo≈øtolicke authoritie, but contrariwi≈øe, to exempt vs from that bondage whereunto this Cardinall through his booke would bring vs: yea, and which he would cau≈øe to ≈øteale in to the buddes of the Flower-deluces, thereby to yoke and curbe the free necks of the Kings of France, which more iu≈øtly then all other Kings of the world may ≈øay, Filij Abrahae ≈øumus & nemini ≈øeruiuimus vnquam. A iudicious per≈øonage of this Kingdome, as ≈øoone as he ≈øaw the diabolicall parricide committed and perpetrated vpon the ≈øacred per≈øon of our late King Henry the Great, and the Queene mother declared Regent, he ≈øaid, that ≈øhee would be vnto our
yong King, as the branch of the Plane tree, or as the Storke is to yer young ones, from whom ≈øhee keepeth off all infection and venome.

And now it is that France expecteth of the ≈øaid Queene Regent, the fruits of the afore≈øaid prediction. For if euer deadly poy≈øon ≈øpread it ≈øelfe ouer the Crowne of France, it is now through this Cardinals Booke, which endeuoureth that the Maie≈øty and ≈øoueraignty of the Flower-deluces, ≈øhould temporally be made ≈øubiect vnto Popes. But alas, great Queene, what pittie, nay what griefe would it be to you, (you being the Tutrixe both of King and Kingdome) negligently to permit all France to be impoy≈øoned through one onely booke?
div.q: Impia nam Pietas po≈ø≈øet ≈øic ve≈øtra videri.
div.p: For may it plea≈øe your Maie≈øty to con≈øider, that in France there are a great number of fal≈øe hearted French men, vnto whom the peru≈øing of this booke is as dangerous as the fome of a mad dogge, when it falleth on any part of a mans body, being already either di≈øea≈øed or vlcerated.

But he which hath written it (Madam) is a Cardinall: and if the con≈øideration thereof take place in your generous heart, it will befall you as it did ≈øometimes vnto King Demetrius, (whom Hi≈øtorians haue ≈øurnamed the indi≈øcreet Prince) becau≈øe after hauing a long time laide a ≈øiege, yea, ≈øweated before the towne of Rhodes, and imployed both his blood and trea≈øure, to become Ma≈øter thereof; hee neuerthele≈ø≈øe at la≈øt did lo≈øe both the honour and
fruit of his victory; for the re≈øpect which he bare vnto a naked picture of Protogenes, which he very ardently loued, and de≈øired to con≈øerue; and ≈øo de≈øi≈øted from battering that part of the towne, where that table was: by which quarter of the towne he might ea≈øily haue ≈øurpri≈øed and taken it.

In the ≈øelfe ≈øame manner (you Madam) vnto who≈øe children the precedent Kings of France haue (for the ≈øpace of twelue hundred yeares) with much care and trauell, reduced the Crowne thereof to all Soueraignty, and acknowledging to hold it of none but of God (though otherwi≈øe mo≈øt religious) haue both daunted and brought to rea≈øon, the Bonifaces and Iulies (authors of ambition, and bladders puft vp with the winde of vaine glorie) are now brought to lo≈øe the libertie of the King your ≈øonne, if you incline and bend your ≈øelfe to admire the dignity of this Cardinall; who is to be e≈øteemed no other then a vaine picture in re≈øpect of the matter whereof he treateth: vnle≈ø≈øe couragiou≈øly you ≈øacrifice not to the fire, the rodde wherewith this impudent Cardinall doth imploy his be≈øt endeuours, to ≈øcourge the Soueraignty of France.

When que≈øtion is to a≈ø≈øault a ≈øtrange Citie, or a Ca≈øtle e≈øteemed impregnable, none vndertake to attempt it without great and notable preparatiues: ≈øo this Cardinall hath long ≈øince both premeditated and propens'd to a≈ø≈øault the ≈øoueraignty of the Crowne of France; which cannot be won without good & valable conditions. For it is a Cat that cannot be ≈øurpri≈øed without gloues: But ≈øift we more narrowly their proceedings.

Fir≈øt at Rome they watered and mollified the Maie≈øty of his chiefe court of Parliament (e≈øteemed at all times the Paladium of France) in the water of the pretext of Religion; contradicting & cen≈øuring his

with the reflex of peeces of a Looking-gla≈ø≈øe, which they repre≈øent them, but neuer da≈øleth the eyes of generous Lyons, which are not affrighted at the remouing ≈øhadow of a light En≈øigne, nor at the apparition of a nocturnall Gho≈øt.

And who will not repute thee feeble, and taxe thee of cowardi≈øe generous France, Lyon of all Crownes (as the Lyon is King of all bea≈øts) if the re≈øpect of a Redde Hatte ≈øhould haue power to ≈øtoppe the cour≈øe of thy independency? It is reported of the Lyon, that with the ≈øound of his voyce he a≈ø≈øembleth all bea≈øts to appeare before him; and therefore thou French Lyon, a≈ø≈øemble, require, and inuite all the Potentates and Princes of Chri≈øtendome, to ≈øee the fraudulency of this ≈øecond Meneclides, who in≈øen≈øibly would throw effeminatnes into the ≈øpirits of Princes, of purpo≈øe to make them become, not tributaries, but ≈øubiects to a Prie≈øt: to a Prie≈øt worthy indeed to be beloued, as long as he maintaineth him≈øelfe Prie≈øt of the world, and Lord or King of his owne territories, without extending his ≈øhooe in Idumea; and ≈øtriuing that tho≈øe which in temporall matters are but ≈øtrangers to him, ≈øhould neuerthele≈ø≈øe in that regard be as homagers and ≈øubiects vnto him.

div.p:

div.p: O wi≈øe Villeroy (vnder the branches of who≈øe fanour and greatne≈ø≈øe, lurke all tho≈øe of the Romane faction, which would wound our countrey) ≈øee≈øt thou not that the confu≈øed light of this Bellarmine, ≈øent amid≈øt the cloud of the variablene≈ø≈øe of France doth pre≈øage our tempe≈øt? and that the fire of his breath, falling vpon the poopes of our ve≈ø≈øels, is the progno≈øtication of the turbulency of our waters? But I fore≈øee that in the end, the tempe≈øtuous ≈øtorm of the≈øe waters will beare downe the Arke of their irregular power of Rome, ≈øo farre, that it will finally fixe and e≈øtabli≈øh it vpon the toppes of the mountaines of Armenia, where it cannot po≈ø≈øibly any longer annoy the Kings of the earth.

He which foundeth this Too≈øin (or Watch bell) wi≈øe Villeroy, is one which hath long admired thee, which knoweth very much of thy proceedings, and who daily weepeth at the diminution of the honor of our natiue countrey: to the ≈øecurity and pre≈øeruation whereof, thy too too great inclination to Rome giueth terrible a≈ø≈øaults and aduantage.

But wherof ≈øhould we feare? the Clergy of France is rich. But now the que≈øtion is of the dignity of the Crowne of France, which ≈øome endeuour to annihilate and extingui≈øh: and therfore who can hinder vs with Themi≈øtocles, neither to put di≈øtinction of wealth, places nor per≈øons, again≈øt the ra≈øh a≈ø≈øertions of Bellarmine, which ≈øeeke thereof to depriue vs? and who can iu≈øtly reproue vs, if with the Syracu≈øans we holily v≈øe our weapons, con≈øecrated to the

And if as ≈øaid Publius Curulius, it was lawfull to ≈øell tho≈øe trees which were mo≈øt deuoutly con≈øecrated to Apollo in the Ile of Coee, to build ≈øhippes for the warres: doubt not Holy Father, but that the Church of France, v≈øe both Fer feathers & her trea≈øures to reuenge her ≈øelfe of the wrongs which Bellarmine in his booke hath offered to the crowne of France: and as the Athenians ≈øaued them≈øelues by the pretious ≈øtones of the monuments of their decea≈øed: ≈øo we likewi≈øe will ≈øtone this Bellarmine to death with the ≈øtones of great Henry, our late Kings tombe; during who≈øe life, if he had publi≈øhed that which he hath ≈øince written, that inuincible King would per≈øonally haue gone and fetched him out of Rome, and ≈øo in expiation of his irremi≈ø≈øible offence, haue immolated and ≈øacrificed him vpon the Altar of the Soueraignty of France.

O Bellarmine, the warre is now denounced betwixt France and thee: and remember that we will v≈øe thee as the Argeans did the Spartans: for whether thou recant liuing, dead, or otherwi≈øe, as long as France is France, not ≈øuch as thou woulde≈øt haue it to be, but ≈øuch as God hath e≈øtabli≈øhed it: thy name among≈øt the French ≈øhall be as horrible and dete≈øtable as that of Ero≈øtratus in Ephe≈øus, who endeuoured in one houre to ≈øacke and raze downe all which rich A≈øia had erected and built in two hundred yeares.

And if thou de≈øire≈øt that thy other books (indeed

Otherwi≈øe nor thou, nor thine ≈øhall euer haue repo≈øe in France, ≈øith thou ha≈øt watched the time of our mourning to make vs ≈ølaues, as did tho≈øe wicked ≈ølips of warre (dete≈øted of olde Iacob) viz. Simeon and Leuy,) which de≈øtroyed the Sichemites in their greate≈øt mi≈øeries and calamities.

Cur≈øed Tarentula, loe we denounce thee warre, and will no longer v≈øe thee as a Cardinall, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt not v≈øed vs as free French men, the fir≈øt borne of the Church. Do≈øt thou imagine to lull vs a≈øleepe, thereby to bring our mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible members into a Lethargy? O felonious Ie≈øuites, which re≈øemble the Nubian Marmorike, that groweth about the body of man purpo≈øely to de≈øtroy it. Sarcophanges of Troade, which will inhabite alone, and de≈øtroy all others that dwell neare you: Combu≈øtible Pyrau≈øtes which by the rayes of your bookes, dart forth a thou≈øand incendies and fires into Kingdomes: enuious Daemons, Telcbnes or Ala≈øtors, which to deceiue the ≈øimple Commons of France, couer your ≈øelues with the thicke cloude of religion, and exhau≈øting the water of ≈øtinking Styx, powre it out on our heads;

But alas, your water re≈øembleth the water of the fountaine of Tellos, which is ≈øo thicke that it cannot bee intermixed with wine, no more then can your helli≈øh and King-killing Doctrine agree with the French.

For although you ≈øeeme faire in your conuer≈øations and bookes, yet God pre≈øerue our Soueraigne Monarchie from being wraped and inuelloped, eyther in your po≈øitions, or in your exteriour apparence; as a Hi≈øtorian ≈øaid, that the rich wals of Babylon (that ≈øeuenth wonder of the world) were neuer ouer≈øpread or touched with Iuy. For as an expert Ma≈øon (of all things) ought not to beautifie his building with that ruinous herbe, becau≈øe in ≈øtead of ≈øtrengthening it, it will de≈øtroy it. So a politicke Prince ought in no wi≈øe permit or tollerate the ≈øect and ≈øociety of Ie≈øuites to re≈øide in his Dominions, what colour of Religion, of ≈øpirituall fruit, or of ≈øaluation of ≈øoules, ≈øoeuer they propo≈øe him; becau≈øe it is to wedde his e≈øtate to the vtter ruine and manife≈øt de≈øtruction thereof, in re≈øpect they vndertake too much, and bu≈øie them≈øelues too much with the affaires of the State.

Know we not by experience, that as the mo≈øt oriente≈øt pearles, by the long and often touching them with lead, are conuerted into du≈øt and earth, ≈øo
the ≈øoules of the mo≈øt re≈øolute≈øt and pure≈øt ≈øubiect becommeth either ≈øilent, perfidious or di≈øloyall through their long fequenting and familiarity with the Ie≈øuites? which haue for their traditiue and rule (like vnto Philip King of Macedonia, who de≈øirous to make peace with the Grecians, required their chiefe≈øt Orators to e≈øtrange them from them;) that immediatly as ≈øoone as they come neare great per≈øonages, they might by their tongue and art ≈øo contriue it, that their mo≈øt loyall and faithfulle≈øt ≈øeruants ≈øhould bee withdrawne from them, to the end that futurely without danger according to his de≈øire, he might the better plot and manage his proiects, without being di≈øcouered.

For proofe whereof, how many excellent men hath father Cotton cau≈øed to be remoued from the Court, to the end hee might domineere alone? And thou, O ≈øweet ≈øpirit, golden tongue, the ornament of our time Fenouillet, how many times haue you beene a≈ø≈øaulted by this I≈ømaell, which could

It is not long ≈øince, that to imprint in the heart of our yong King, he ≈øhould make v≈øe of none but the Ie≈øuites, and reiect and ca≈øt off all others: this iugler reported

Briefly as we reade that Iupiter with one ≈ømall chaine, very ea≈øily drew al the other Gods after him, and him≈øelfe could bee drawen by none of them: ≈øo the Ie≈øuites in their Troublexiue of Gretzerus, report and write (Being a barrell of wine, and a filthy lodge ≈øtinking of lyes and bla≈øphemies) that this Cotton is the Kings Ma≈øter; that his Maie≈øtie heareth no other Ma≈ø≈øes then his, and that hee gouerneth the Queene Regent; and yet the learned Prelates of France well know that he him≈øelfe is a puny, and in effect nothing.
